docs.lead_paragraph: IT is the habit of some minds to ignore the salient points of any matter and the attack undue importance to what is trivial. A writer of several books on English says that of the numberless questions addressed to him, almost all concern utterly insignificant disputes, such as whether it be proper to say "to-morrow is Monday" or "to-morrow will be Monday," a matter not worth a moment's thought.

headline.main: MORE ABOUT "GOOD ENGLISH"; Some of the Expressions which Are in Popular Usage in This Country and How One May Avoid Them
